title: secondary schools shut longer over
story: Secondary schools may shut for longer over Christmas to get students tested for CovidTory MPs called on the Education Minister to ensure schools will remain open in the New Year to avoid safeguarding hazards and mental health related issuesNicola Sturgeon said she was not considering closing schools Image: Getty ImagesByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsSecondary schools may shut for longer over the Christmas holidays so pupils can get tested for Covid, the Government has said. Education Minister Alex Burghart said extra funding has been put in place so schools can test their pupils before heading back into the classroom. But Tory MP Robert Halfon, chair of the Commons Education Select Committee, said he fears we are moving towards de facto school closures, despite the Ministers assurances. Downing Street warned parents not to take their children out of school before term ends, responding to suggestions some parents kept their kids at home to protect them from Omicron. The Prime Ministeraposs spokesman said: “The best place for children – who have in many respects suffered the most through this pandemic – is in school, receiving vital face-to-face education.”  He added: “It’s important schools – and indeed parents – don’t take precautionary steps to deprive their children of education”. Responding to a barrage of claims that schools may close, Mr Burghart told the Commons Government remains committed to ensuring schools reopen in January as normal, amid fears the spread of Omicron will keep kids at home. And he insisted the classroom is the very best place for children and their development. Mr Halfon said: “It seems to me we are moving sadly towards de facto school closures”, as he urged the Government to create an “army” of volunteers and public awareness campaign for the education sector. “The four horsemen of the education apocalypse have been galloping towards our young people in the form of a widening attainment gap, an epidemic of mental health problems, a rise in safeguarding hazards and a loss of le chances, he added.  Mr Burghart outlined the measures that will be enacted in schools to keep Covid at bay. They include on site lateral flow testing onfor secondary school students, continued regular testing at home and a comprehensive contingency framework to manage potential outbreaks. Tory MP Lia Nici echoed Mr Halfonaposs calls for better messaging, so parents and students feel safe ing to the classrom. She told the Commons: We need to make sure that parents understand that itaposs more important for the children to be at home and then not to be afraid. Could he just make sure that that we get the message out now to parents to say school is safe and school is the best thing for your children  Former health minister Steve Brine highlighted union calls for a staggeredin January, adding: “What is the Government going to do legally to see that its will is enforced and that schools are back, as they should be, as they need to be in January ” Shadow schools minister Stephen Morgan accused the Government of “complacency” on pupils’ health and education, claiming ministers were “falling short” on the issues of vaccination and ventilation in schools. He said: “Time and time again this Government’s failure to plan ahead has left children bearing the brunt of the pandemic. Ministers must stop treating them as an afterthought and act now to avoid chaos next term.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Shaun BaileyNadhim ZahawiConservative PartyNew YearEducationSchoolsMental healthSecondary schoolChildcarePoliticsChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: third day frustration over access
story: Third day of frustration over access to tests and jabs as new Covid Pass rules kick inChief of UK Health Security Agency, Dr Jenny Harries, says the NHS is seeing "unprecedented demand" for Covid tests and that a "very rapid rise" in people trying to secure a kit is causing "temporary pressure"Brits were seen standing in snaking queues while waiting for their vaccine booster shotByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Brits wanting to test for Covid are becoming frustrated over struggles to keep up with the surge in demand for the third day in a row.Official Government websites tell users that Lateral Flow Tests and PCR are currently not available. It comes on the day of the Covid Pass roll out, which will make it mandatory for members of the public to present a vaccine passport to enter some venues. And for the third day people were forced to stand in snaking queues outside vaccination centres while waiting for their third booster dose. Speaking of the shortages, UK Health Security Agency chief Dr Jenny Harries said the spike in test seeking has caused temporary pressure. Dr Jenny Harries said the NHS is experiencing unprecedented demand for PCR tests.She went on: We had already planned to increase capacity over the winter, because we predicted a dficult winter. We clearly couldnapost predict a iant like Omicron. We have some flexibility there. We currently have about , tests per day available. If you go back to when we had no tests, or very few, about , I think going back to autumn last year, this is a huge achievement. She added: Yesterday the public may have seen some pressure on some of those sites. Iaposm in Wales. Some of the test sites here will be at seven per cent or eight per cent capacity. In London, they were quite full. People can still order tests at home, and we have put in mobile testing units to try and boost those supplies so people can get tested. So we do have sufficient tests both for PCR and LFTs . But the very rapid rises is causing some temporary pressure.  On Monday, Brits rushed out in their thousands to get a booster jab in a bid to save Christmas as Omicron sparked fears of another locked down festive period.Since then, members of the public were spotted queuing for hours outside vaccine centres. But as people rushed to do the right thing in the battle against the mutation drive, the NHS booking website crashed.Those arriving at vaccination centres faced five-hour long queues and online lateral flow tests ran out. Last week Boris Johnson announced his Plan B to deal with the sharp increase in Omicron cases.Speaking at a Downing Street press conference, the Prime Minister said the doubling time of the new strain could be between two and three days - meaning its spread will be rapid. Under the stricter rules people must show a Covid vaccine passport to enter some venues in England. Butsomeone is unjabbed they can still enter as long as they produce a negative lateral flow test. Covid passports will be made mandatory for nightclubs and large events, and rules on face masks would be “further extended” from Friday, to “most public indoor venues” including theatres and cinemas. story: Crying dog tied up and left outside Asda in pouring rain for over two hoursChristine Jones was shocked to spot a dog tied up in the rain outside the Asda store in Woodchurch, Wirral, in Merseyside, at around pm on MondayThe dog was left crying for two hours Image: Liverpool ECHOByAnnie Williams:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA crying dog was abandoned outside Asda in the pouring rain for over two hours, it has emerged.Christine Jones went to Asda in Woodchurch, Wirral, in Merseyside, at around pm on Monday when she spotted a dog tied up in the rain outside the store.She said the dog was in a clear state of distress and was barking continuously so she went over to stroke it and reassured it that their owner wouldn’t be long.While shopping Christine said she continued to hear the dog’s ‘anxious’ barks echoing through the store which started to concern her, reports the Liverpool Echo.She told said : “When I was shopping I could still hear it while I was in the store - still barking and barking.“I kept looking at my phone while I was walking around to keep an eye on the time and how long it had been out there.  “At this point it was half past three, so after I paid I was going to go over and speak to customer services and ask them to put out an announcement for the owner as this dog was clearly getting more stressed.” Christine, who worked in a veterinary practice for  years before opening her own arts and crafts shop in Moreton, said when she approached the customer service desk there were already two other women voicing their concerns about the dog outside to an Asda colleague. Due to a store policy, Christine and another woman were told an announcement was not able to be made so they ed to the dog outside and discovered three more people had come to the dogaposs rescue. Two schoolgirls were among those trying to help and had moved the dog out of the rain and got her under shelter. Christine, , said: “The two young girls were great the entire time. “They were both just offering to do all kinds. aposCan we do this  Can we do that apos, they were brilliant. They stayed with the dog the whole time and just offered to do everything they could. “The youth of today get such a bad rap but they’re not all bad at all. Christine said she and another woman, who took the dog home, had contacted Birkenhead Kennels. After the incident Christine took to Facebook to thank the girls who stayed to help and offer them a voucher for their help. She wrote: Can I just day the two school girls from Woodchurch High were brilliant in helping with this situation andthey pop to Pigmentum in Moreton there is a voucher waiting for them there from me as a thank you for their help.” The post has been shared over  times and people flocked to praise the girls and the women involved. One woman wrote: “Well done to everyone involved for caring, I truly hope the situation is resolved for the dog ASAP. A second woman said: “Aaah God love her. She must have been terried! Hours on her own waiting for her owner to . Thank you to the lady who took her in and to the girls who helped. There are are some very kind and compassionate people around. While a third commented: “Hopefully a happy ending here. Well done Woodchurch girls. Hopefully it was undercover, Itaposs been raining all day I dread to think. A further two people commented to say they had also seen the dog outside the supermarket around pm but assumed the owner must have been inside the store. Christine said the circumstances of the dog are still unknown and despite putting the information on Facebook, nobody has claimed the abandoned dog. The Moreton shop owner said: “All I can only say about the dog is it did look really healthy and in good shape. It was really friendly and obedient as one of the girls told it to sit while I took a photo of it to post and it listened straight away. “Her collar looked nice, her lead looked nice so we can’t jump to any conclusions on what has happened - there could be lots of reasons behind it.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AsdaCustomer serviceTeamDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Drawing bought for £ at yard sale turns out to be lost masterpiece worth £mExperts believe the unpublished artwork, titled The Virgin and Child with a Flower on a Grassy Bank, was produced by German Old Master Albrecht Durer in The artwork, titled The Virgin and Child with a Flower on a Grassy Bank Image: Agnews BNPSByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA drawing bought for £ at an American yard sale is now expected to sell for a staggering £ million after it was found to be a lost Renaissance masterpiece. Experts believe the unpublished artwork, titled aposThe Virgin and Child with a Flower on a Grassy Bankapos, was produced by German Old Master Albrecht Durer in . The .ins by .ins pen and black ink drawing on fine linen paper, which is signed with the initials AD, is now being sold by London art gallery Agnews after extensive research confirmed its provenance. It came to light in  when a man aged in his s spotted it and bought it for the modest sum at an estate sale in Massachusetts, US. The American buyer was struck by the unframed drawingaposs beauty but both he and the seller believed it was a th century reproduction.  Clford Schorer, an art dealer for Agnews and a Durer expert, was informed about it from an antiquarian book dealer three years ago after the new owner had tried without success to sell it. He agreed to take a look at it himself and visited the vendor who presented the drawing to him on his dining room table. Mr Schorer stared at it for an hour as he was blown away by its aposmagnicenceapos, instantly thinking it could be the aposreal thingapos. From there, he set about authenticating the drawing, showing it to museums and experts including Dr Christop Metzger, chief curator at the Albertina museum in Vienna. Crucially, world renowned paper restorer Jane McAusland, who also inspected the drawing, identied Dureraposs aposTrident and Ringapos watermark. Mr Schorer said: I thought it was too beautul to be  and have spent three years seeking to authenticate it. I have shown the drawing to almost all the international Durer specialists to build a consensus . I believe this drawing is rarer than Raphaelaposs , and could fetch a record price. It is an extremely important addition to Dureraposs work, who is one of the Renaissanceaposs biggest names, and it is a once in a letime find. story: Exact date to begin isolation so you can safely see family and friends on Christmas DayWith a surge in cases of the Omicron covid iant, its important to be cautious when socialising. Dr Jeff Foster explains how to stay safe, while also keeping your family safe this ChristmasIf youre planning on heading home to see family or loved ones for Christmas, you should be taking some Covid safety precautions Image: Getty ImagesBySurena ChandeSEO Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Itaposs been a tough year and, while there have been new restrictions introduced due to Omicron, families and loved ones are still able to reunite for Christmas . There are now reportedly  people in hospital with the Omicron Covid iant, and it may already be infecting an estimated , people daily in the UK, according to modelling for the government. While reuniting with family and friends is a welcome relief towards the end of the year, itaposs crucial to be careful when youaposre out and about and take precautions to reduce your chances of becoming infected with coronavirus. And,youaposre wondering how to keep your family as safe as possible at Christmas, we spoke to Dr Jeff Foster, Medical Director  Male Health Lead at hhealth, to find out some top tips. When should I isolate from so I can safely see my family at Christmas  While there is no official date outlined for keeping your family safe at Christmas, it is important to take precautions prior to visiting family for Christmas. Dr Jeff Foster tells : It certainly appears Omicron is more infective than previous iants and may also spread earlier. We know that the time from exposure to symptom onset, also known as the incubation period, is two to  days. However, he also explains that you can be asymptomatic for several days prior to feeling unwell and testing positive. Therefore, you should ideally isolate from around December ,  , up to six days prior, before seeing family or friends on Christmas Day. This will allow you to see whether you have any symptoms, and it also gives you plenty of time to get a PCR test result should you come into contact with someone whoaposs tested positive for Covid or the Omicron iant. And, there is also a risk of unintentionally infecting people you come into close contact with as you may not be aware of your symptoms instantly. Dr Foster says: You are not likely to be infectious for the first  hours of exposure as you wonapost have built up enough virus to be able to spread it to someone .Read More If you want to reduce your chances of spreading the virus, you should be regularly testing with lateral flow tests, particularlyyou feel any Omicron symptoms. The unusual Omicron symptoms to look out for ahead of visiting family this ChristmasWhile Covid symptoms for the iants have fairly similar characteristics, South African Medical Association chair Dr Angelique Coetzee, revealed that a key dferentiating symptom with Omicron is headaches on Tuesday, December .She said: Evenyou wake up with a slight headache, not feeling well, please come and let us [GPs] double check. Another potential Omicron symptom mentioned by Dr Coetzee was myalgia, so you may feel muscle soreness or body ache. If you begin to feel unwell and have any cold or flu-like symptoms, or even a headache, be sure to take a rapid lateral flow test as soon as possible and avoid socialising. Due to the incubation period, youaposre unlikely to test positive on a PCR test instantly, so Dr Coetzee recommends waiting  hours before testing.  Dr Jeff Fosteraposs tips for staying safe at Christmas and avoiding the spread of coronavirus If youaposre planning on heading home to visit family and loved ones this Christmas, Dr Jeff Foster recommends following these measures to keep yourself and others safe. . Get vaccinated Dr Foster says: This is the best thing you can do. One year on, we can see the massive benefits the vaccine has had in reducing hospitalisation and death. We also know that while there is some reduction in its effectiveness over time, the booster still has signicant protective effects even on the Omicron iant. The government aims to have offered all of the UKaposs adult population vaccinated with the booster jab by the end of .All adults in the country are now able to go to walk-in centres for their booster jab, or will soon be contacted to book an appointment.. Wear a mask As self-explanatory as it sounds, wearing a mask is one of the best ways to signicantly reduce your chances of getting Covid. Dr Foster explains: There are people that believe is an imposition on their liberties and rights, but overall the evidence is that it reduces the spread of the disease.  It is not a terrible imposition to ask, it harms no one and it may help save an elderly or vulnerable personaposs le. . Ventilation is key While comfort and cosiness is key at Christmas, itaposs worth keeping windows open throughout the house whenever possible when youaposre with your family during the festive season. Revealing how much of a dference it makes, Dr Foster says: Covid likes stale and still air where it can be breathed in again and again. You will not get covid from breathing a single virus, but it is about breathing enough of it in to trigger an immune response and allow the virus to spread. Keep your windows open and circulate the air. This disperses the virus and reduces the chance of breathing it in.. Hand sanitiser Another factor thataposs absolutely crucial when out and about or on public transport is using hand sanitiser and washing your hands frequently. Keep a mini bottle in your pocket or bag and sanitise your hands throughout the day to avoid spreading the virus. Dr Foster adds: In addition to breathing it in, touching something a virus has had contact with and then touching our faces is a common way we get a lot of viruses including covid. Wash your hands and give people a ready supply of hand gel. story: Family demand action after being forced to wade through sewage in garden for yearsWilly Wardlaw says the plumbing issue has been ongoing for “four to five years”, over which period he has been "fobbed off" with quick cleans rather than proper fixesWilly is calling for a permanent fix to the problemByStuart McFarlane:,  Dec | commentsA man who has lived in a flat where plumbing issues see raw sewage flushed into his garden is calling on his water provider to sort it out. Willy Wardlaw, who lives with his we and two children in Stirling, Scotland, says the issue has been ongoing for “four to five years”. It repeats every time there is heavy rain in the area, he said, leaving his young family having to wade through waste on their way out of their home. He has been left angered by the efforts of Scottish Water to address the drainage problem, claiming he has been “fobbed off” with quick clean ups, rather than action to reverse the blocking issues.Willy told theDaily Recordthe issue had been going on for “years”.  “It’s about the fourth or fth time this year that it has been covered with sewage,” he said. “The main drain comes down the side of our street and backs up waste and toilet paper into our garden, meaning that my kids have to wade through it, as well as my elderly neighbour downstairs who can’t get out of her door. “We’ve been in touch with Scottish Water a few times about it, but they just send someone out to clean it up. “The guys who are sent out to clean it up do a great job, but they need to fix the source of the problem because the next time it rains, it’ll just happen again.  “We’ve written to them and contacted their Facebook page about it, but we don’t hear from anyone up the tree, just the guys who are sent out to clean it up.In response, a Scottish Water spokesperson said: “We are aware of an issue with sewer flooding at this property and have attended on a number of occasions to deal with blockages, clean the sewer and carry out clean-ups of the affected area. “Last week, Scottish Water operatives were in attendance and carried out investigations. We would like to reassure the customer that further survey work is now being planned to establish the cause and a possible solution to help avoid future blockages.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Daily RecordFloodsSewage" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. symptom of the Omicron iant of Covid - back pain.Ryan Noach – chief executive of South Africaaposs largest private health insurer Discovery Health, said lower back pain was being reported as a common symptom. Discover Health conducted the research into the , cases and now have listed the symptom as myalgia - muscle aches and pains.Experts in the UK have already identied that Omicron tends to have very dferent symptoms from other iants of the disease.Normally people are asked to look out for a fever, persistent cough and loss of sense of taste or smell as signs of Covid.  But now Omicron is reported to give symptoms more like a common cold - a scratchy throat, runny nose, sneezing and headache. The symptoms are considered similar to a common cold - but experts have warned that in London,you think you have a cold, itaposs actually more likely to Omicron. The first UK cases of Omicron were only confirmed on November  and the speed of its spread has alarmed ministers and prompted a dramatic acceleration of the booster jab programme. Boris Johnson has set an ambitious target of one million jabs a day and to ensure the roll out is continuous, people will even be able to get their booster shot on Christmas Day. The UK Health Security Agency has previously projected that Omicron could become the dominant iant across the country by the middle of the month. So far one person is confirmed to have died from the Omicron iant - but their age or vaccination status isnapost known. NHS England have scrapped the -minute wait for patients after theyaposve have their Pfizer Covid jabbed to speed up the booster programme.  They have done away with the quarter-of-an-hour sit-down so more doses can be administered. The isolation rules have also changed, with those who have come into contact with a positive case expected to do a daily lateral flow test. But there are currently no PCR Covid test slots left in some areas of England. A top medic has warned that Covid restrictions could be needed for up to eight weeksmodelling on the impact of the Omicron iant is correct.Dr Susan Hopkins, chief medical adviser to the UK Health Security Agency , said there would need to be some level of restrictions in place for the next four to eight weeksestimates by the London School of Hygiene  Tropical Medicinewere accurate.Scientists at LSHTM said the new strain could cause between , to , deaths in England over the next five months after examining experimental data. Evenbooster jabs are found to be effective against Omicron, they projected a wave of infection which could lead to a peak of more than , daily hospital admissions.  Dr Hopkins was grilled about the need for restrictions by the Commons Science and Technology Committee. Asked by Tory Committee chair Greg Clark on the exit strategy from Covid curbs, she said: This is our fourth time going into something like this. The waves last a period of time and the more the restrictions are effective, then the smaller the peak, and therefore you can reduce andle to normal.She said boosting the population was likely to reduce hospitalisations - and limit the strain on the NHS.Asked when restrictions could be lted based on the modelling so far, she said: So I think thatthe modelling that the London School has done [is right], I would expect that there is going to be needing some level of restrictions in place for the next four to eight weeks.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Back painOmicron iant" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: four times more people self
story: Four times more people to be self-isolating this Christmas Day than , report claimsOver one million Brits could be spending Christmas alone this yearthey get a positive result on a Covid test - as experts warn the Omicron mutation could be infecting , people each dayFour times more people could be isolating this December  compared to last yearByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec  A surge in Covid and Omicron infections could send four times as many Brits into isolation this Christmas Day compared to last year, official data suggests.Data released predicts more than one million people could be forced to miss December  celebrations while following Government containment measures. And another threat looms as official models predict cases of Omicron are doubling every two to three days - infecting , people daily, it has been reported. Professor Chris Whitty, Englandaposs chief medical officer, warned ministers at a Cabinet meeting yesterday that the mutation is spreading at an unbelievably fast rate. The rapid transmission will send four times as many Brits into isolation compared to Christmas , according to estimates. Regular cases of Covid are also at a high, with , new infections recorded yesterday. This represents the highest daily figure since January and an increase of  per cent compared to last week. Meanwhile, doctors have been identying patients suffering with Omicron. There have been a total of , infections recorded after a further  cases were logged yesterday.  Brits who test positive for Covid today may also be alone this Christmas. People are legally required to self-isolate for  days on receipt of a positive Covid test, eventhey donapost have symptoms. If symptoms are developed during those  days, the additional -day isolation would lead to Christmas being missed. The rules available online read: “If you are isolating because of a positive test result but did not have any symptoms, and you develop Covid- symptoms within your isolation period, start a new  day isolation period by counting  full days from the day following your symptom onset.” Leading virus experts fear Covid hospital admissions could reach , a day amid concerns about the Omicron spike. Infectious disease scientist, Graham Medley, told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: Most of the infections at the moment are in young adults, so these are people who are far less likely to need hospital treatment in any case.But in the past, in previous waves, weaposve seen that move out into more older and more vulnerable generations and thereaposs no reason to suspect that wonapost happen during this wave. And then the numbers of people who end up in hospital is some combination of when people get infected, their vaccination status, as well as what Omicron is doing. I think it is a very real possibility thatthe numbers of infections increasing continues in the way that it has done and it spills out into older age groups than we could see the number of people being omitted to hospital getting very large and certainly going over the thousand, maybe up to , a day, the scientist, who works at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, added. Cabinet ministers have also been warned that the NHS could be overwhelmed in a matter of just four weeks. Ministers are said to have been told so many doctors and nurses could be off sick by January  that those left will struggle even more than now to care for patients.  Likewise ministers were told some pubs, shops and restaurants could have to shutstaff shortages leave them high and dry, according to reports. The Sun originally reported that ministers were warned some hospitals could have to turn patients away, but this was denied by Downing Street. The PM’s spokesman insisted there had not been any discussion or any warning about hospitals or clinical settings having to close as a result of this iant. He added: “We have strong measures in place and robust, and now tested, procedures in place to ensure [public services] can continue. Latest figures suggest  known Omicron patients are in hospital but numbers are expected to surge as more cases are detected.Health Secretary Sajid Javid said he was unable to confirm any deaths from the new strain - but warned there is a lag between infections, hospitalisations and deaths.He said there country was facing a tidal wave of infections as the Government launched a mammoth booster programme to battle the Omicron emergency. title: key evidence morgue monster david
story: Key evidence in morgue monster David Fullers trial from DNA to horric hard drivesDavid Fuller abused over  corpses of victims, ranging from nine- to -years-old, and also pleaded guilty to the infamous Bedsit Murders. Heres the key evidence that led to his le sentenceThere was a mountain of evidence against David Fuller, who pleaded guilty Image: PAByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Dec | comments Family photographs, DNA evidence and millions more depraved images led to murderer David Fuller receiving a le sentence. Fuller pleaded guilty to his crimes and was sentenced after admitting to the murders of Wendy Knell, , and Caroline Pierce, , both from Tunbridge Wells in Kent. He will never be released from jail.He admitted to murdering the women days into his trial, and had previously admitted manslaughter by diminished responsibility. The victims were found beaten and strangled, in , in horric incidents that became known as the aposBedsit Murdersapos. Ms Knellaposs body was found at her flat in the June of that year. However, Ms Pierce was found  miles away in Romney Marsh, her naked corpse found in a field after going missing in November, .His crimes stretched over three decades, and the court revealed a history of abuse of corpses in mortuaries in a tidal wave of grim evidence and the revelation of shocking events.The DNA evidence  The Bedsit Murders remained unsolved for over  years until DNA evidence led to Fuller. Cold-case detectives carried out a review of the national DNA database, which showed a close match to  people. This was eventually narrowed down to Fulleraposs brother, who partially matched samples taken from the crime scene in . Fuller, himself, was then revealed to be the killer, his DNA a billion-to-one match.  A prowler had been reported by victim Caroline Pierce one month before her disappearance. The prowler fitted the profile of Fuller. The prosecutor said: A male of a similar profile to Fuller had been seen looking through an address near to Wendy Knell on the same night. Fingerprints and family photos  The trial didnapost just rely on DNA evidence as, once Fuller was identied, he was swtly matched to other pieces found at the scene of the crimes. A bloodied Millets bag was found under victim Wendyaposs bed. It had a fingerprint on it that was a match to Fuller. Clarks footwear archivists also helped police to track down the bloody shoe marks found that belonged to a aposSportstrekapos trainer.  These shoes were then seen being worn in a family photo album by Fuller during the s and s. DS Ivan Beasley spoke about telling Wendy and Carolineaposs families of the arrest. He said: It was real, genuine shock. They had thought this day would never come. Clearly it has brought back a huge amount of emotion, trauma and grief. Depraved content on hard drives  An unexpected, but utterly horric, element of the case was the revelation of Fulleraposs other crimes. As well as the guilty murder plea, he also pleaded guilty to  other offences. This involves  charges relating to  identied victims, including three children, in mortuaries between  and November . They include the sexual penetration of a corpse, possessing an extreme pornographic image involving sexual interference with a corpse and the taking of indecent images of children.  Investigators have, so far, detected roughly  potential victims but conceded that all their identities may never come to light. Police raided his home in Heathfield, East Sussex, on December , , where they discovered hard drives with more than  million images of distressing sexual offences. These included images of him sexually assaulting dead bodies. Fuller had access to the bodies by working as a hospital electrician. He worked at the Kent and Sussex Hospital from , before moving on to Tunbridge Wells Hospital in . A jury at Maidstone Crown Court heard on Monday, December , , that Fuller had depraved sexual predilections and had attacked corpses for an extended period of time at the hospitals where he worked. You have proved that monsters exist  The ages of the bodies abused ranged wide, with one victim aged just nine-years-old. The childaposs mother said: It makes my skin crawl and it really does break my heart. I feel sick. I can’t sleep. It will haunt me forever. Ahead of sentencing, the daughter of a victim of the crimes was able to speak out.  She said: You have proved that monsters exist. You were cocky, arrogant and despicable. You are the worst of humanity. My mother was a survivor of domestic violence. It is almost too much to know that a man abused her again when she died, just because he could, for his own sexual gratication. story: Labrador bids final farewell to favourite cafe and emotional customers after  yearsBarney the Labrador, , has spent the last  years visiting the cafe in Ballyhackamore, and his owner wanted him to have one final chance to say goodbye to the much adoring publicA Labrador has made a final journey to bid a fond farewell to his friends in his local town Image: Annne CookeByJilly BeattieKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments A Labrador has made a final journey to bid a fond farewell to his friends in his local town, having spent  years bring light to the locals around him.Barney, from Ballyhackamore in East Belfast, lived to the grand old age of aged  and half - or  in human years. For over a decade and a half he has been a familiar face in the local community, having originally trained as a police dog but becoming a family pet when a working le was deemed unsuitable for him.Restaurant owners, shop and cafe workers came out for Barneyaposs goodbye, while his owner Anne did her best to hold back the tears, Belfast Live reports.  In the end, everyone wept for the big old dog who’d bounded into the le of the area and left to go home on stf legs, his belly full of treats, the end of his journey within sight. Anne said: “We’d held on as long as we could to Barney. We maybe should have let him go earlier but we just couldnapost and he didnapost want to go, we knew that. But one day he gave us the look and we knew it was time, he was tired, he was ready. His hips had become very stf and sore but worse than that he’d developed a tumour in his nose and mouth. So we knew the end was coming but it was hard to contemplate le without him, and it has been heartbreaking to say goodbye not only for us but for all the friends heaposd made along the way. “But as with everything, we did it for him, we did our best for Barney every day and saying goodbye was the kindest but hardest of them all. “All of his letime with us he’d had a daily routine of a walk through Ballyhackamore where he knew the staff in every cafe and shop. In that way he was really the community’s dog. He brought a smile to so many faces and his cafe friends told us his visit was the highlight of their day. For  years we did the rounds with him, his favourite stop off was at Cafe Nero where he always enjoyed a croissant and a cuddle.” Barney began police training aged nine months where he was trained to be an explosives detection dog. But while he showed talent for detecting explosives and bombs, Barney had no interest in staying with them until his handler arrived. So he was given up by the police as a lovely but unreliable police officer. Anne said: “Barney was our constant companion, everyone’s go-to ear for a chat, everyone’s hug, a comfort to us all. He was such a big softie, and after two changes of home, he made ours his last and he stayed with us for more than  years. “When it came to the day we knew we had to say goodbye, we knew we needed others to have that chance too. So we walked slowly to the coffee shops and everyone had a chat and a cuddle and a cry and everyone got to say their goodbyes to one of their best customers. He took his time and we let him. I honestly think he knew what was going on. It was emotional and dficult but also a great comfort to us and to his friends. “We went home again for a rest and then we went out to Seapark in Holywood where Barney had spent thousands of hours running and this time he just enjoyed the snfs and a lie down. Then we took him to McDonald’s where he enjoyed two cheeseburgers. But they knew they wanted Barney to slip away on his favourite spot on the sofa, and said their vet Steph did everything to ensure he could pass with them right by his side. She gave him a sedative and he just slipped away on his spot on where he slept all of his le, and then Steph gave him the last injection and he was gone. Weaposre so grateful to Steph to have allowed us the luxury of home care for Barney, it was so gentle, there was so much care taken over him. We know he wasnapost distressed but it broke our hearts and they’ve been broken ever since. It was the most awful honour to be able to help that last moment pass with dignity. Steph stepped out and let us have a lot of time with Barney afterwards and when we were ready, she wrapped him in a cosy blanket and carried him in her arms to her car. We have his ashes home now and we will always keep those. “Our home feels very empty with Barney, the leather settee he nibbled the covers off it still sitting with his blanket in place, his collar and lead are still hanging on the hook. “We’ve cried so many tears over this big dog, he was a gt to us and he held us together all of his le. He might have been a failed explosives dog but we knew his talents lay where, and so did he. title: life booster jab volunteer harrods
story: Le as booster jab volunteer - Harrods-sized queues and tears after Boris bombshellAdam Perry, , a procurement specialist who has been a vaccine volunteer since January, describes what its like being on the front line of the booster driveOne of the biggest issues we’ve had over the last few days has been the sheer number of walk ins – particularly when they start impacting on waiting times for people who have booked Image: Adam Gerrard   Daily MirroropinionByAdam Perry:,  Dec | comments When I turned up for my sht this week I couldn’t believe the crowds – it was big as the Harrods sale. People had been queuing since am, even though we didn’t even open until .am. The vaccine centres were given no early warning about Boris Johnson’s announcement and had not been able to prepare for the sheer numbers of people turning up that we’ve been seeing since Sunday. It was like opening the floodgates and letting all the water come rushing through. When a service like this relies on volunteers – people who have jobs and who aren’t always available – it’s been a logistical nightmare to get people to help.And when it comes to the queues, while most people are happy to accept there will be a wait, there are still people who think itaposs worth their while to shout at the staff helping. That doesn’t help anyone, so to calm things down I tell them that Iaposm a volunteer and just trying to do my best.  I’ve been helping out at my local vaccine centre, at a clinic in Crouch End, North London, since January. Iaposm normally there once a week with a clipboard at the door helping check people in, taking their temperature and directing them to where they need to go. It got me out of the house when everyone  was locked down, it’s been an incredibly rewarding experience and I’ve met people I would have never normally talked to in my daily le. While the NHS may be providing the vaccine service, it relies on volunteers to run it smoothly, from data inputting to greeting, to even giving people vaccines.  One of the biggest issues we’ve had over the last few days has been the sheer number of walk ins – particularly when they start impacting on waiting times for people who have booked. At my instigation, at our clinic we now have two queues so that people who have booked times aren’t waiting as long. While it can be stressful, a busy day at the vaccine clinic can be exciting. Everyone is working closely as a team, there’s an adrenaline rush, as well as a huge satisfaction in knowing that we are helping, that people will feel safer when they leave. But we also have to be extra careful not to make mistakes.  One of the hardest things is keeping on top of who is allowed a vaccine and when. There are strict rules about how long it should be since their last vaccine, there are also age limits and no amount of pleading from them can make us give them the jab - we aren’t making the rules. I’ve had people break down in tears because they can’t have their jab. They swear that they know more than us that we are telling them a lie. That’s one of the hardest things - I really didn’t sign up to stand around in the freezing cold for hours at a time to be shouted at. But usually people are calm and grateful – at the start of the vaccine programme they would even bring us chocolates and cakes. It’s immensely satisfying to be part of this huge push to keep everyone safe and I would recommend it to anyone who can help. where many Brits are coming down with seasonal colds. Every winter there is a rise in common colds and other respiratory infections.Earlier in the Autumn Brits were dealing with theworst cold ever , after theto schools and the end of coronavirus restrictions. But now coronavirus infections are rising, and with the new Omicron iant on the rise, Brits need to make sure their colds arenapost actually Covid.Although believed to be more transmissible, there have been reports that Omicron is causing mild symptoms. So how can you be sure itaposs a cold and not Covid  Hereaposs everything you need to know. What are the symptoms of Omicron   The symptoms of the Omicron iant of coronavirus appear to be very dferent from previous strains, according to researchers. Some are reporting mild symptoms that are dferent the Delta strain.Early reports show Omicron has five district symptoms of its own, which are:A scratchy throat sore throat A dry cough Extreme tiredness Mild muscle aches Night sweatsHowever, according to the NHS website, there are still three main recognised symptoms of Covid. They are: A high temperature A new, continuous cough A loss or change to your sense of smell or tasteWhat are the symptoms of a cold   According to the NHS, the symptoms of a cold can come on gradually, and include:A blocked or runny nose A sore throatHeadachesMuscle aches Coughs A raised temperature Pressure in your ears and face Loss of taste and smellHow can you tell the dference between a cold and Covid   As many of the symptoms of Covid and a cold are the same, it can be tricky to know which ones you have. Professor Tim Spector previously appeared on This Morning to clear up any confusion.He explained to Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield: “Many people - perhaps up to half of cases - are going unrecognised because they basically have symptoms that are very cold-like. So headache, sore throat, runny nose, sneezing - and the only one that gets into the top five is loss of smell or taste.Weaposre now seeing that fever is very low down on the ranking of what weaposre seeing at the moment. Even rarer are things like shortness of breath or a persistent cough. Itaposs a combination of factors but weaposve got to face the reality which is, most people out there with Covid are presenting with cold-like symptoms.” What should you doyou have Covid symptoms   Itaposs incredibly important thatyou have any of the symptoms of Covid-, including the ones associated with Omicron, you should get tested. Professor Tim Spector, from Britain’s Covid Zoe app, said it was more important than ever to get tested. Data from the Zoe study app suggests that about half of all the Delta cases are being missed because they donapost present the classic Covid symptoms. He added: Omicron is probably more, much more similar to the mild iants we’re seeing in people who have been vaccinated with delta than anything . And so it is going to be producing cold-like symptoms that people won’t recognise as Covidthey just believe the official government advice. Professor Irene Petersen, a professor of epidemiology and health informatics at University College London , added: “A runny nose and headache are symptoms of many infections, but may also be the first symptoms – and only symptoms – of Covid. story: Oxbridge students spiked with needles on exclusive skiing trip to the French AlpsReports on social media suggest at least six students, including a man, were targeted last Thursday in the French Alps resort of Val Thorens during the annual Oxbridge skiing tripAerial view of Val Thorens Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByTom Ambrose:,  Dec | commentsSix students believe they were spiked with needles or in their drinks during the annual Oxbridge skiing trip to the French Alps last week. The group of students, which included at least one man, claim they were targeted at the Val Thorens resort and could have had a substance slipped into their drinks.Another incident was reported to have taken place two days earlier, according to the Daily Mail.Joe Hilton, co-president of the Varsity Trip ski holiday, said the spikings could have been carried out by Oxbridge students after it emerged that the incidents at the ‘Slipped Disc’ club night happened before am, when the general public was allowed in. One student told Cambridge University newspaper Varsity: I do not know why there is the presumption that Oxbridge students cannot spike people and it must be locals – this happened early on a student night.But another wrote on Facebook that a group of middle-aged men with seemingly no relation to the Varsity Trip had been allowed into the club with no pat-down search .There were reports of a large crowd of what seemed like locals trying to get into the club via the back entrance and that there was presence from Nuco, which organised the trip for , students. A student wrote on a social media group that their friend had been spiked at Malaysia with a needle, according to Varsity, while Nuco posted warnings, saying it has increased door searches.  At am on Friday, Oxford law student Maeve Carroll posted on Facebook: There are now five girls we are aware of who have been spiked by injections drinks tonight. Nuco and security are aware but seem to be doing not much. There were also comments from female students, some who were so scared that they said they had put on long sleeve tops and coats to protect themselves. None of the alleged incidents had been reported to the police yet, according to Mr Hilton. Nuco Travel added that its staff had taken over the door at the venue after reports of spikings and aggressive door staff who reportedly turned away  people despite having tickets. story: Revellers enjoy last night of freedom before Covid passes are needed at clubsRevellers have been hitting bars and nightclubs and having festive fun in fancy dress as they enjoy the final day of "freedom" before new Covid restrictions come in on WednesdayHundreds of people headed to a nightclub in Portsmouth on Tuesday night Image: Paul Jacobs pictureexclusiveByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsParty-goers dressed up as Father Christmases and other festive figures were in high spirits as they headed to crowded bars and nightclubs around the country to celebrate the last day of freedom before Covid passes are enforced. With many people in festive spirits they have been heading out to parties and drinks with friends before new restrictions are introduced in an attempt to slow the spread of the Omicron iant. In Portsmouth hundreds of people flocked to a themed night at the Astoria nightclub. People could be seen dressed up in their Christmas gear with plenty of Father Christmases and some snowmen on show. And it was not just Tuesday night as last weekend thousands were out in towns and cities for festive fun.  Little regard was taken for the highly contagious new Covid iant which is forcing the new rules from Wednesday. People will need to show that they have had two vaccine doses or a negative test in order to go into nightclubs and some other venues. The government has said that lateral flow tests should be used by people entering “high-risk settings like crowded places.  Nightclub owners have hit out at the new restrictions saying that a lack of rapid COVID- tests will make enforcement a big challenge.Last week, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced his Plan B measures to tackle the spread of the Omicron iant.The UK has registered almost , cases of Omicron, with  people hospitalised and one person dying after contracting the iant.  New rules were passed in Parliament on Tuesday though  members of Johnsonaposs own party voted against them. Kate Fuller, who owns the Electric Ballroom nightclub in Camden in north London said the lack of available rapid testing is a problem for her. Since the announcement of the restrictions, our business just took a massive downturn, she said.  Thereaposs no testing in a lot of the pharmacies. If you canapost get the tests, itaposs going to be really hard for people to come. I think for our security and everything, implementing these is just going to be, you know, a big challenge. The new rules will apply to unseated indoor events with  people or more, unseated outdoor events with over , people and events with more than , attendees.  Clara Cullen, venue support manager at charity Music Venue Trust, which supports around  music venues in the country, said there had been an increase in cancellations with income falling by % in the past week. There will be financial implications to trying to implement the Plan B, said Cullen. story: Schools prepared for closure in January over fears of Omicron Christmas surgeA number of schools in the south east of England have reportedly told parents to make sure children take all their books and devices home in their final days of term — in case online learning s in the new yearA number of schools have already closed for Christmas due to staff shortages Image: Getty Images Image SourceByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments Schools are already reportedly making emergency plans to remain closed in January over fears of an Omicron Christmas surge grow. Currently, it is estimated , are absent from school due to Covid.It comes as a number of schools have already closed for Christmas due to staff shortages - with once academy chain saying  per cent of staff are off.A number of schools in the south east of England have reportedly told parents to make sure children take all their books and devices home in their final days of term — in case online learning s in the new year. Steve Chalke, head of the Oasis Academy chain, said his plans include theof bubbles, rota lessons and staggered start times. He told The Sun : “We are quite prepared for online learning. If we get to January  and the Prime Minister says all schools need to be shut, we are prepared.“January is the great unknown. But Omicron is sweeping London now and it is going to sweep the country.”The UK Health Security Agencybelieves the Omicron iant is causing around , new infections per day.The staggering figure raises questions about whether there will be a need for fresh restrictions, with Boris Johnson refusing three times to rule out doing so before Christmas.  Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon could announce extra restrictions.And Deputy PM Dominic Raab insisted there were no plans to bring in further restrictions on top of Plan B measures being voted on by MPs later today.Weaposve got none planned, he said when asked about new Covid curbs. story: UK families will be able to spot Santas sleigh this Christmas - heres howFamilies in the UK will be able to look out into the sky and see Santa in his sleigh just before am on Christmas morning - heres exactly where to lookFamilies will be able to spot Santas sleigh just before am on Christmas morning Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByNeil SHawEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Dec | comments Itaposs hard to believe where the time has gone, but Christmas really is just around the corner, which means in just over a week children all over the country will be peering into the sky hoping to catch a glimpse of Santa Claus. And,you want to make sure your little ones get a look at the big man in red as he finishes off delivering presents, you can do so in the UK just before am on Christmas morning - so long as the weather is clear. According to WalesOnline, Families should be able to spot Santa in the morning sky at .am on December , where heaposll appear from the west - so you best get your compass at the read. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Mr Claus will then rise high in the sky - reaching degrees above the horizon, in a pass across the UK that will last six to seven minutes. The sleigh will then disappear over the horizon to the East South East. Santa has to fly pretty high, so what youaposll see will be a magical bright white dot streaking across the sky - but it will be clearly visible with the naked eyethe weather is good. To be in with the best chance of spotting the sleigh you can download an app that tracks the International Space Station - the sleigh happens to be following the same route. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-arctic-winds-"UK Weather: Chart forecasts snowfall as temperatures dropByTim HanlonNews ReporterAlice Peacock:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBrits are in for a freezing Christmas period and will need to wrap up even warmer as the year draws to a close with snow expected around the New Year, it has been forecasted. As the country recovers from snow and gales from Storms Arwen and Barra, the mild temperatures have continued over the past few days after it reached a balmy C last weekend. Temperatures are expected to plummet to below freezing next week over Christmas, according to WXCharts, as a weather system is forecasted to bring frost and foggy conditions. Brits have been warned that another named storm could hit over this period, with the potential to bring mph gales, rain and a drop in temperature next week. It comes after Storms Arwen and Barry killed at least four people and caused widespread chaos, with tens of thousands of homes losing power. Forecasters have said the chances are not high of a white Christmas, with the Met Office predicting a “predominantly dry and settled” period in the days leading up to the holiday.However, a British Weather Services forecaster has said the potential for snow after Christmas was high, with the possibility of a white New Year. A cloud cover is expected to reduce as the year draws to a close, with a corresponding increase in the risk of overnight fog and frost as we move past Christmas.  According to Met Office forecasting, there will be rain at times in the far north and northwest over this period, along with some stronger winds. Temperatures would hover around or just below average, with mild weather expected in the north and colder conditions in the south. Overnight frost and fog was likely in places heading towards the New Year, with unsettled spells most likely for the northwest.The Met Office stated: “Heading deeper into January there is expected to be a gradual sht towards more changeable conditions, especially in the northwest, and turning milder again too.” Met Office spokesman Grahame Madge told the Mirror an area of high pressure, a bit like a dome, would become increasingly established and will sit over the UK over and well beyond Christmas.  It will create conditions that might provide a lot of cloud, Mr Madge said. There might be some drizzle and patchy rain from that, but we’re not expecting anything drastic. Mr Madge said temperatures would also drop over this period.Jim Dale, of British Weather Services told the Express : “The main two factors in the short term will be dry weather and fog. At times the fog will be dense and will sit in valleys. The main hazard will be ice on roads, this side of Christmas,” said Mr Dale. He continued: It will be a pseudo white Christmas. This means frost instead of snow. It will certainly be cold enough for snow, but there will be less moisture in the air to form snow. The weather will become progressively colder as we move towards Christmas.” Mr Dale said: After Christmas, there is a northeasterly cold air coming. It will get properly cold after Christmas with the possibility of a white New Year. The potential for snow will be high after Christmas. There is a cold pool over Europe and we could be left open to this polar air over the New Year.  UK forecast for the next  days Today: Some sunshine in northern Scotland, north Wales, and parts of northern and eastern England. Many other areas cloudy some rain across west and south Scotland, Northern Ireland and Cumbria, and patchy drizzle in the south. Mild. Windy in the north. Tonight: Rain pushing northeastwards across western and northern parts of Scotland. Still a little drizzle possible in the south. Some cloud breaks in between, which may lead to some fog patches. Thursday: Any fog in central and eastern England may be slow to clear. Some sunshine possible, mainly parts of northeastern UK. Still damp in the far north. Elsewhere cloudy but dry. Outlook for Friday to Sunday: Mostly dry but rather cloudy. A few sunny intervals, while clear spells by night could allow patchy fog. Winds mostly light but temperatures trending downwards, with patchy night frost possible. story: UK weather: Met Office predicts exact date snowbomb and bone-chilling artic weatherFollowing treacherous weather after Storm Arwen and Barra the UK has experienced unseasonably warm temperatures this week, however that’s set to change just a couple of days after ChristmasWeather forecasters, Netweather.tv, have predicted that on December  temperatures will plummet Image: PAByGabriella ClareLeigh Mcmanus:,  Dec | commentsBritain is set to be blasted by a snowbomb in the final weeks of December with severe gales and heavy winds forecasted. Following Storm Arwen and Barra the UK has experienced unseasonably warm temperatures this week. However that’s set to change just a couple of days after Christmas. Weather forecasters, Netweather.tv, have predicted that on December  temperatures will plummet and brutal conditions will commence with five storms before the end of winter, My London reported. The new storm, dubbed Storm Corrie, could see cm of snowfall in the north west of the UK.  Speaking to The Sun, British Weather Services meteorologist Jim Dale said: “We are expecting one more major storm this month which will set the trend for coming months. We expect five to six storms to hit through the winter period which could be severe enough to warrant naming. However, it looks like London will escape the blistering conditions of the storm but may still experience some snow.  BBC Weather predicts that December  will be C with sleet showers and a gentle breeze.Weather forecasters WXCharts have mapped out where snow is predicted to fall, demonstrated by a wall of purple on the map.The Met Office has issued a long term prediction for the long festive weekend, including the date Storm Corrie is expected to wreak havoc.“In general, cloud amounts will tend to reduce with time, with a corresponding increase in the risk of overnight fog and frost, which may be slow to clear by day in some areas.“There will be a slight chance of rain at times in the far north and northwest, with some stronger winds here .“Temperatures will generally be near average, and locally mild in the north, but perhaps rather cold at times in the south and feeling chilly where any fog persists.”UK forecast for the next  days This Evening and Tonight: Rain and drizzle will move northwards across Northern Ireland and Scotland. Elsewhere, mostly dry but rather cloudy for most. Some clear spells, mostly across northeast Wales, northern, central and eastern England, where some frost and fog is possible. Thursday: Rain clearing the far north of Scotland. Mostly dry but rather cloudy across many areas, with fog perhaps slow to clear eastern England. Some sunny spells, mainly in the northeast. Outlook for Friday to Sunday: Generally dry and cloudy with light winds, though a few sunny intervals are likely, especially for parts of Scotland. Temperatures slowly decreasing, with patchy overnight fog and frost in places. story: Covid Christmas deadline: Rules on seeing familyyou catch coronavirus from todayFrom Wednesdayyou catch the virus you have to self isolate at home for  days - up to and including December  - as the Omicron iant spreads across the UKPeople who live alone will not be able to visit friends and familythey test positive from tomorrow Image: Getty Images Image SourceByKelly-Ann MillsReporterKaisha Langton:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The final day for testing positive for coronavirus and still be able to see your family on Christmas Day has been and gone.From todayyou catch the virus you will have to self isolate at home for  days - up to and including December  - in a bid to stop the spread of Covid currently sweeping the country following the emergence of the Omicron iant.There are currently  people in hospital with the new strain and cases are rocketing. MPs voted on Plan B Covid restrictions on Tuesday as Health Secretary Sajid Javid announced all countries would be removed from the UK red list. Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned a huge spike is on the way, with Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty telling the cabinet he expects a signicant rise in hospitalisations driven by the Omicron iant.The latest Covid data showed , new infections were reported in the UK on Tuesday, which is up from , reported the week before on December  - the highest rate of new cases since January Plan B restrictions are currently in force across the UK. Measures designed to combat the Omicron iant have thus far included new guidance related to face masks and working from home. Compulsory vaccines for health and social care workers are also due to be introduced from April . However, the Prime Minister had to stare down a rebellion from his own backbenchers who disagreed with some Plan B proposals, including COVID passes. It was the worst rebellion against the government since he became PM.However, the Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer threw his support behind the governmentaposs Plan B this week - meaning restrictions were voted through.Can I travel and stay over at my familyaposs home this Christmas Christmas was essentially cancelled for many last year, with heartbreaking stories of those isolated alone hitting the news. But this year, there are currently no restrictions in place which would prevent you from travelling to visit your loved ones this Christmas, so long as you are not forced to self-isolate due to a positive Covid result or other mandatory quarantine reason. No plans have been outlined by the PM or his ministers suggesting there are plans to introduce restrictions on domestic travel over the festive period. Mr Johnson has promised, this Christmas will be considerably better than that of . However, new Covid rules have been introduced across the UK in a bid to respond to the rapidly rising rates of Omicron.What happensI test positive while at my familyaposs home this Christmas If you have any symptoms of coronavirus, including a high temperature, a new and continuous cough or a loss change in your sense of taste or smell, you are required to self-isolate immediately. You are also required to get a PCR test as soon as possibleyou have any of the above symptoms. If you test positive for COVID-, you have the virus and therefore must self-isolate at whatever location you are currently residing in. This means,you test positive while at your familyaposs home over the festive period, you must remain there for  days starting from the day your symptoms began or the day you had the testyou did not have symptoms.You can find out more about how long to self-isolate here.If you have tested positive you should inform the NHS and anyone you have been in close contact with for the past  hours to ensure they can get tested. These contacts are not required to self-isolate unless they are contacted by the NHS Test and Trace service.  Does everyone in your family home or household have to self-isolateyou test positive for COVID- If you live with someone with Covid, you will not need to self-isolateyou meet any of the following criteria: you are fully vaccinated , you are under  years and six months old, you are taking part or have taken part in a Covid vaccine trial or you are not able to get vaccinated for medical reasons. If iniduals meet any of the above conditions, those fully vaccinated are advised to do daily rapid lateral flow tests for seven days, limit social contact with anyone at higher risk from Covid and follow advice on how to avoid catching and spreading the virus. However, NHS Test and Trace will contact anyone who has come into contact with someone with Covid by phone, email, text or through the NHS Covid- app and inform themthey need to self-isolate. If someone is contacted by NHS Test and Trace, they are required to self-isolate, eventhey are fully vaccinated. NHS Test and Trace will advise iniduals on the self-isolation procedures depending on their vaccination status.  What do I dosomeone in my household tests positive  Do I need to isolate as well  The government updated its guidance on Tuesday. It reads: If you live in the same household as someone with COVID-, and you are aged over  years and  months and not fully vaccinated, you are legally required to self-isolate. This does not applyyou have taken part in or are currently part of an approved COVID- vaccine trial or you are not able to get vaccinated for medical reasons. Do not go to work, school, or public areas and do not use public transport or taxis. Your isolation period includes the day the first person in your household’s symptoms startedand the next  full days. This means that , for example, your  day isolation period starts on the th of the month, your isolation period ends at .pm on the th and you canto your normal routine. The government reiterated that they class a household as either:one person living alone a group of peopleliving at the same address and who share cooking facilities, bathrooms or toilets, or living areas and may include students in boarding schools or halls of residence groups of people who share a nomadic way of le for example those who live on Traveller sites, in vehicles or on canal boats WhatI get the Omicron Covid iant Omicron is rapidly becoming the most dominant iant around parts of the country and therefore positive cases are likely to be this new strain. It is likely to become the dominant strain in the UK in a matter of days. The rules for Omicron and other Covid iants are all the same - and therefore you do not need to take any extra stepsyou have Omicron or not. The World Health Organisationhas said PCR tests can detect Omicron infections. The Omicron iant has multiple mutations to its spike protein, which is found on the virus’s surface. The spike protein plays a role in infecting cells and most PCR tests target several parts of the viral genome, including the S-gene that encodes the spike protein. The new iant appears to cause milder cold-like symptoms. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here.Can I travel abroad this Christmas The red travel list will be scraped in England, according to the Health Secretaryaposs announcement on Tuesday. Mr Javid revealed it will no longer be necessary to block arrivals from the  banned countries where Omicron has been discovered, given there are now thousands of cases of the iant already in Britain. In terms of travelling abroad, you are able to travel abroad as you wish - depending on the rules of the country you intend to travel to. There are currently  countries that have essentially banned UK visitors, including Australia and New Zealand. Can I take daily tests and leave isolation early If your rapid lateral flow test comes back positive, you should continue to self-isolate until you get the result of the PCR test. Evenyour PCR test is negative, you may need to quarantine. In England,you do the PCR test within two days of a positive rapid lateral flow test and your PCR test is negative, you can stop self-isolating. If you do the PCR test later than this, youaposll need to self-isolate for  full days evenyou get a negative PCR result.What should you do about childcareyou have to self-isolate Those aged under  years and six months old are not required to self-isolatethey live with or have been in contact with someone with Covid. According to the latest guidance, anyone aged five years and over who lives in the same household as someone with COVID- and who is not legally required to self-isolate is now strongly advised to take a lateral flow test every day for seven days. If any of these LFD tests are positive they should self-isolate in order to protect other people. WhatI need to go to work to pay my bills You are required to stay at homeyou have tested positive for coronavirus - this means you cannot go to work, school, other public areas or use public transport.The government says you may be entitled to a one-off payment of £ through the NHSTest and Trace Support Payment schemeyou are required to stay at home and self-isolate and unable to go to work. You can also get supportyou are the parent orof a child who has been told to self-isolate. Your local authority websiteshould explain what you need to do. You can also get practical support to access food and prescription medicine while you are stuck inside. What happensyou breach self-isolation rules  Failure to adhere to the mandatory quarantine rules could mean you face a fine of at least £,. Parents or s are legally responsible for ensuring that anyone under  self-isolatesthey test positive for COVID- and are contacted by NHS Test and Trace and told to self-isolate. story: Worrying Covid graph shows Omicron cases in London now rising faster than first waveData from the UK Health and Security Agency reported that  per cent of cases in London were caused by Omicron earlier this week but now it is closer to one in twoCommuters make their way across London BridgeByTom Ambrose:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsOmicron is now the dominant Covid- iant in London, new analysis suggests.Some .% of a sample of new coronavirus cases in London with specimen dates for December  and  were found to have S gene target failure- a way of detecting the likely presence of Omicron.Most samples of Omicron that have been sequenced in a laboratory have been found to contain a slight but identiable dference from other Covid- iants such as Delta. This dference - a deletion in the S gene - shows up in certain laboratory PCR tests and can be used as way of estimating the spread of Omicron. Of the , Covid- cases in London recorded on December  and  where the S gene status could be determined,  were classed as SGTF.  The figures, which have been published by the UK Health Security Agency, also show that .% of a sample of detectable cases in eastern England from December  and  were classed as SGTF, along with .% in south-east England and .% in north-west England. A graph put together by Oliver Johnson, Professor of Information Theory at the School of Mathematics, University of Bristol, plots the Covid cases reported by London onto a graph. Publishing it on Twittter, he said “since we know that omicron is growing at a similar rate in most regions, with ious places being about a week behind London.  Then it might be prudent to imagine that the next few places on this list might also see a big steepening in cases in the next week.” Levels were lower in all other regions, with north-east England having the lowest estimate of .%. The level for the whole of England was estimated at .%. All figures are based only on samples tested at four of the UK Lighthouse laboratories - Alderley Park, Glasgow, Milton Keynes and Newcastle - which means there are likely to be parts of the country where the prevalence of Omicron is underreported. Prof Tim Spector, an epidemiologist, told BBC Radio ’s Today programme: “In London, where Covid is increasing rapidly, itaposs far more likely to be Covid than it is to be a cold.“We’re seeing doubling in the numbers equivalent to what’s being seen where, every two-and-a-half days, and that really means numbers are going up. “If we look at our regional charts we see London accelerating more than we’ve seen it since the very first wave and this now means that Omicron is the predominant iant already. “We’ll be at  per cent very soon, so that’s happened in just a matter of days – that’s is why so many people are going down with infections.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Coronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
